item.title: Old in Art School
item.description: _( )_ I finished reading “Old in Art School”, by Nell Painter, this afternoon on my commute home.

item.title: Dear Poet, To Survival
item.description: I had no answer except I love Frank O’Hara which I didn’t voice because I knew it was not the answer.

item.title: Book Report: “The No Asshole Rule”, by Robert Sutton
item.description: My annual review at Creative Commons took place at the end of July, and like last year, the emphasis was on the growing area of focus for me: management.

item.title: Reading Update: Short Reviews
item.description: I’ve been delinquent in posting about what I’ve been reading.

item.title: Read: “Django 1.1 Testing and Debugging”, by Karen M. Tracey
item.description: Packt Publishing sent me a copy of `Django 1.

item.title: Preread: “Django 1.1 Testing and Debugging”, by Karen M. Tracey
item.description: Another Packt Publishing title is on the way for review, `Django 1.

item.title: Read: “Grok 1.0 Web Development”, by Carlos de la Guardia
item.description: A month and a half ago I posted a pre-review of `Grok 1.

item.title: Read: “Invisible”, by Paul Auster
item.description: There are a few authors who I’ll follow just about anywhere; Paul Auster is one of them.

item.title: Pre-read: Grok 1.0 Web Development
item.description: |image0| Late last month I received an email from Packt Publishing (en.

item.title: Meta: What’s up with all the Reading?
item.description: So far this year, I’ve published seven posts with the tag “reading “.

item.title: Read: “Spooner”, by Pete Dexter
item.description: Spooner, Pete Dexter’s latest novel, is not as consistent as The Paperboy , but that does not make it inferior.

item.title: Read: “Fordlandia”, by Greg Grandin
item.description: Fordlandia chronicles the rise and fall of eponymous rubber plantation established by Henry Ford in Brazil in 1927.

item.title: Read: “The Paperboy”, by Pete Dexter
item.description: I picked up The Paperboy after reading about Pete Dexter’s most recent novel, Spooner , on NPR.

item.title: Ugly, Pretty, Special
item.description: Another example of the power of young adult fiction .

item.title: Read: “When You Reach Me” and “First Light”, by Rebecca Stead
item.description: I just finished reading First Light, by Rebecca Stead , after reading When You Reach Me earlier this month.

item.title: Read: A Single Man, by Christopher Isherwood
item.description: I picked up Christopher Isherwood’s 1964 novel, `A Single Man http://en.

item.title: Read: The Cactus Eaters, by Dan White
item.description: I recently completed a writing class focused on creative non-fiction, specifically autobiography, or memoir (the course title used the former label, but “memoir” seems to be the label most often used for the genre).

item.title: Book Review: Java 5.0 Tiger: A Developer’s Notebook

item.title: Reading about Writing
item.description: I think it was as shocking to me as it was to Garrett when I confessed “I really want to be a writer,” on our second date.
